text: Patient: Okay. Is that the – Doctor: Xtandi. Patient: Xtandi. Okay. That was a shot once a month or? Doctor: That was the pills you were taking. Patient: Oh, I did take them. Yeah. Okay. Doctor: So that would say if we did that just as a course of action and the likelihood it’s gonna help you is pretty low. Patient: Oh. Doctor: And so, this study is looking at a new therapy –uh, the hottest new drugs that are out there, and when we’ve given them to men with prostate cancer, we haven’t seen a whole lot. (Pause) Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Um. And the two drugs together, uh, may be, uh, cause responses. Uh, but we don’t know. And that’s why we’re doing a research study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we’re giving folks who’ve got bad disease this because the worry is these drugs may have a lot of side effects. Most of the time, they’re tolerated well, but what they do is they turn on your immune system, hope that your immune system is going to attack your cancer, but I also could turn on your immune system with these medicines and it attacks you. Okay? So you can get a pneumonia that’s from your immune system. You can get hepatitis because it’s attacking your liver. You could get colitis ‘cuz it’s attacking your colon. Uh, it usually picks one organ, not not all of ‘em, but, you know, you can get into trouble because your immune system – while it’s tryin’ to fight your cancer, it’s tryin’ to fight you. Uh. And when we Patient: I see. This is from the – both the uh– the, uh, both of the –

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay and I did mention to you that your testosterone is also going up. Patient: Right. Doctor: However, I think given the fact that you’re feeling relatively well. text: Patient: That’s a done deal. Doctor: So, again, only that thing is, you know, if it, we don’t start ‘til early January. Then, you get six cycles. So, then we’re talking March. The surgery may not be ‘til April or early May. Patient: Any of those other things they oughta, where, like the, the hormones - let them ride for a little while before chemo. Any other - Family Member: Good to knows? Patient: Good to knows. (Laughs) Doctor: Yeah. Uh, some of it’s style. Okay? So, my sense is, you know, there’s a number of us doctors who are appointed patients under the study, and the study allows a lot of wiggle room, uh, for how we approach it. Uh. It’s a little concern of mine that all of us could do a little bit differently. But, you know, there’s general consistency about how to do it. So, for me, it’s a style that, uh, giving hormones and chemo together, uh, you can really drop your counts out if you haven’t given it a little bit of space. So, one of the other doctors just gives a lower dose of the chemo, and, uh, like, like, okay, but I would rather make sure you get a full dose of chemo, a full dose of hormones, and if I just space it out a little bit, then we can probably keep that safe. Patient: Now, space it out a little bit, and I grabbed the number third of January, just outta the air. When you say “space it out a little bit,” from the beginning of the hormone treatment till, is it a week, ten days, a month? Doctor: Uh. Patient: Before you would start? Doctor: I mean, so we - in other studies, we’ve had up to about a four-month window that we could get the chemo started. In this study, it’s sorta that there is a definition, I think you said-- Healthcare Professional: It’s, umm. You’re talking about the protocols and parameters? Family Member: Yeah, the study itself. Doctor: Yeah. Thirty or sixty

text: Patient: You know, it was a little, uh I was really hoping that this would start the numbers to decrease, that was what I was anticipating at the very beginning, but I knew there was a possibility that they would be going up. So just a little disappointed – Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - that they have been going up. I think that the thing that kept me most uh calm with it was that they weren’t increasing you know as fast as they were before I went You know a person coming into the study with um, I think it was around four when I really started noticing the stuff going and now we’re somewhere around twenty-eight, twenty-nine. Family Member: Twenty-eight. Patient: Yeah. So you know. But that was (chuckles) Doctor: But it, it has slowed down a little bit, you know we design studies you know, we want things to slow down but really what we want to see is you know, huge and immediate increases. So we always sort of go for the home run and then sometimes you know we might get a single and double, Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: but you really want to go for the home run. So we do not have a home run. We all know that by now. We have patients on this study where um they get the same drug you’ve got or the same dose – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - and their PSA drops by ninety-eight percent in the first two months. We’ve seen that. You’re not one of those guys. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We also have other people where the PSA continues to increase at the same pace or in some people it even speeds up. So you’re not in that category either. Then we have some people where the PSA you know slows down, they stay on the drug for anywhere between four to six months. It’s probably doing something, but it’s not know the desired effect or the absolute you know, perfect effect that we expected, so it’s sort of a middle ground, and yet it’s hard to justify you know to keep going if all you’re seeing is like a lukewarm type of response. Patient: Right, right, right.

text: Patient: No. Today I did. Doctor: So that was your first one ever? Patient: Uh-huh. Doctor: Okay. Okay. So because of your PSA going up, we checked scans. The bone scan tells us that, huh, you’ve got a lot of cancer in your bones. We sort of knew that from before even though we haven’t had a picture of that, and so, again, when they talk about what this looks like I have nothing to compare it to. Huh, but this is you, your body, these things here represent the cancer. So here’s your back bone, also a lot of it here in your ribs in multiple spots, a couple of areas on the skull bone that look like there’s cancer there, or one area in this, huh, your right, your left leg. Huh, huh, and then the CAT scan says, huh, that’s what we had used at the very beginning, huh, which says that basically all the areas in the bone that they saw before are still there, huh, with, huh, additional spots. Huh, and you’ve got some really small lymph nodes down in your pelvis. All that is doctor lingo for, huh, you know, you’ve had benefit from the hormone therapy, huh, but I really can’t tell you how much worse it is because these are the first real pictures since you’ve gotten started. You’re hanging in there, huh, but it would be, you know, time to change therapy. Family Member: Okay. We know. Patient: So what kind of pills can I take? Doctor: Huh, so the most common pill would be a drug called abiraterone or enzalutamide. Huh, if you’ll excuse me one second, I’ll ask one colleague a question. I’ll be right with you. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: The enzalutamide, what you were saying- Family Member: Let him, let him, let him ask a colleague a question. He’ll be right back. Patient: I mean I’m just- Doctor: Okay. You remember it?

Patient: I mean I’m just- Doctor: Okay. You remember it?

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so you’re set there. And there’s probably nobody out there right now. Patient: Right. Doctor: I always end up with you late in the day. Doctor: At least you don’t have to go to the ER tonight. Patient: Right. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? So then I’ll let you head out and, huh, we’ll check on whether the trial makes sense. So I’ll say, read the consents, we will review your records to see if eligible, because if you need blood, I can give you a blood transfusion, but the hep C we may not be able to. Patient: Right. Doctor: This tells you, you know, you can read the consent. We’ll review your records to see if you’re eligible. Otherwise, we can start the chemo in a few weeks. Stop the abiraterone now. Continue on the prednisone. It says stop the abiraterone, and it tells you on this page that I refilled your ibuprofen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then it says that, huh, I refilled your ibuprofen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
